Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I stare at my screen, the bug report blinking in my inbox. QA flagged a minor UI glitch—nothing catastrophic, but it’s been popping up for some users. There’s a simple workaround, but management expects quick fixes, and I know my team relies on me to keep things running smoothly. I’m about to dive into the code when my phone buzzes. It’s a call from a legislative aide—one I’ve been trying to reach for weeks. They have ten minutes to talk, right now, about the bill I’ve poured my heart into. My activist side screams at me to answer, to seize this rare chance to push for real change. But my developer self feels the weight of my team’s trust and the company’s expectations. My heart pounds as I hover between the phone and my keyboard, torn by the demands of both worlds, knowing I can’t give my best to both at once.
